column2: officially the City of Malolos (Tagalog: Lungsod ng Malolos)
column3: is a 3rd class component city and capital of the province of Bulacan
column4: Philippines. According to the 2015 census
column5: it has a population of 252
column6: 074 people.It is the capital city of the province of Bulacan as the seat of the provincial government.The city is 45 kilometres (28 mi) north of Manila
column7: the capital city of the Philippines. It is one of the major suburbs conurbated to Metro Manila
column8: situated in the southwestern part of Bulacan
column9: in the Central Luzon Region (Region 3) in the island of Luzon and part of the Metro Luzon Urban Beltway Super Region.

column1: Malolos was the site of the constitutional convention of 1898
column2: known as the Malolos Convention
column3: that led to the establishment of the First Philippine Republic
column4: at the sanctuary of the Barasoain Church. The convent of the Malolos Cathedral served as the presidential palace at that time. Malolos gave birth to the first constitutional republic in Asia.

column1: Adelantado Don Miguel Lopez de Legazpi conquered the 8 villages along Malolos River and integrated it into one entity dated November 14
column3: and constituted it as an Encomienda de Malolos the  Adelantado entrusted the settlements to conquistador Don Marcos de Herrera. On April 5
column5: Legazpi merges the encomiendas of Malolos and Calumpit into a  single entity to form a new town of Calumpit with Juan Moron and Herrera as co-encomenderos.

column3: Legazpi entrusted 6 villages along Atlag River and given it to Don Jeronimo Tirado.Nine years later
column4: Malolos was officially established as a town and included it in Bulacan and dismembered on Alcaldia de Calumpit on June 11
column5: 1580 and accepted as priory with Fray Matheo de Mendoza as its first minister in an Augustinian Council held in Tondo Convent but the civil administration still belongs to its encomendero at that time
column6: Don Jeronimo Tirado.

column4: Gatmaitan
column5: Gatsalian (Gatchalians)

column1: Chinese traders settled in Malolos starting in 1670
column2: due to economic progress in town. They setlled here and married the natives. The settlers are increasing
column3: and Malolos began engaging with texile
column4: rice production. However
column5: the Chinese are expelled from this town on June 30
column7: due to its political and social scandals.

column3: the town of Malolos was divided into three independent towns; "Malolos"
column4: "Barasoain
column5: and "Santa Isabel". These new towns are former districts of Malolos
column6: with own  respective Presidente Municipal and Parish priests. With the beginning of American rule in 1903
column7: these towns were again reunited into a single municipality. The two other districts became barangays under the political jurisdiction of Malolos.

column1: A major factor in Malolos' growth and development was the opening of the Manila–Dagupan railways or Ferrocaril de Manila-Dagupan (Spanish) in April 1892. With the advent of the railroad came new ideas from Manila and other places. Another factor is Malolos proximity to industrial and business centers.
Malolos was first organized into a formal municipal unit in 1822 when the first "alcalde constitucional" or municipal head was appointed. He was Jorge de Victoria
column2: a Filipino
column3: who like all succeeding "alcaldes"
column4: served for one year. He was followed by thirty-one other "alcaldes"
column5: with Juan Dimagiba as the thirty-first. In 1859
column6: Malolos was subdivided into three administrative districts; Malolos
column7: Barasoain and Santa Isabel. Juan Dimagiba became the first "alcalde" of the down-scaled Malolos. There were 12 others who served as "alcaldes" from 1859 to 1879
column8: the first one being Mariano C. Cristobal and the second being Capitan Tomas Tanchanco
column9: whose term marked the start of civil turmoil in the town.

column1: Malolos is the historical site of the constitutional convention of 1898 that led to the establishment of the First Philippine Republic
column2: the first republic in Asia
column3: led by Emilio Aguinaldo. Malolos served as the capital of the short-lived republic from 1898 to 1899. In 1899
column4: after the Malolos Constitution was ratified
column5: the Universidad Scientifico Literaria de Filipinas was established in Malolos
column6: Bulacan. It offered Law as well as Medicine
column7: Surgery and Notary Public; Academia Militar
column8: (the Philippine's First Military School) which was established on October 25
column10: (the Philippine's first law school) and an exclusive school for boys.

column1: The Congress of the Revolutionary Government of the Philippines convened in Barasoain Church in Malolos on September 15
column2: 1898. On the 18th
column3: Aguinaldo proclaimed Malolos as the capital of the Philippines. The first important act of the Congress was the ratification on September 29
column5: of the independence proclamation at Kawit
column6: Cavite of June 12
column7: 1898. On October 19
column9: by virtue of an act of Congress
column10: the Universidad Literaria de Filipinas was established. It was in Malolos on December 20
column12: when Gen. Emilio Aguinaldo declared December 30 of every year as a day of national mourning. The greatest achievement and for which the Malolos Congress was known was the framing of the Malolos Constitution
column13: prepared by a committee headed by Felipe Calderón
column14: was approved by the congress after amendments have been made on January 20
column16: sanctioned by Aguinaldo the next day and promulgated on January 22. The last congressional act of the Malolos Congress was the inauguration of the Philippine Republic with Aguinaldo as the President on January 23

column3: at the height of the Philippine–American War
column4: Aguinaldo ordered Gen. Antonio Luna to set the Malolos Cathedral including its huge silver altar on fire as part of their strategy called "Scorched-earth Policy" where everything will be rendered useless. Malolos was totally destroyed when the Americans captured the capital. Aguinaldo escaped to San Fernando
column5: Pampanga before the American Forces arrived at Malolos.

column1: === Malolos as the capital of Bulacan ===
More than a year after the 1899 Battle of Malolos and the victory of and occupation by American forces
column2: the national seat of power was officially conferred again to the City of Manila and on February 27
column4: by the virtue of Public Law Number 88 of the Philippine Commission
column5: the commission officially transferred the capital  seat from the heavily damaged nearby town of Bulakan to the Town of  Malolos and it became the capital of Bulacan.

column1: The Casa Presidencia de Malolos was converted as the new Casa Real of Bulacan (became Casa Real Shrine) making it as the new Official Office and Residence of Governor until 1930 when the new Provincial Capitol Building in Barrio Guinhawa
column2: also in Malolos was built.

column1: === Governments of Malolos after the Philippine–American War ===
During American Period  After the War
column2: the Americans appointed a martial law administrator in the person of Jose Reyes Tiongson. He served as "presidente politico militar" from 1901 to 1902.  With the capture of Pres. and Gen. Emilio Aguinaldo in Palanan
column3: Isabela and the defeat of most of the Filipino armed forces all over the country
column4: the Americans began to put up a network of local government units. The municipality of Malolos was re-organized
column5: composed of the districts of Malolos
column6: Barasoain and Santa Isabel. Appointed "presidente municipal" or town mayor was Ramon Gonzalez de Leon of Sitio Tampoy
column7: (grandfather of TV host Joey de Leon) one of the original members of the Katipunan Balangay Apuy. He was in the post for two years
column8: 1903 to 1905.  He and the nine others who followed him were all appointive officials. When the Philippines became a commonwealth
column9: Leon Valencia was elected mayor in 1937
column10: the first ever elected. Diosdado Dimagiba succeeded him in 1940 but had to vacate the position because of the Japanese conquest. Also in this period
column11: the Malolos Municipal Hall facing the Malolos Church was built
column12: in a manner of Neo-Classical Roman Style.

column1: During Japanese Occupation  The Japanese appointed two "punong bayan" or mayors
column2: Luis Peralta and Ignacio Tapang. After the joint US and Philippine Commonwealth armed forces liberated Malolos in March 1945
column3: Adonis P. Maclang of the guerrillas' Bulacan Military Area was appointed guerrilla mayor of the town
column4: before battle for the liberation of Bulacan
column5: the local Filipino forces of the 3rd and 32nd Infantry Division of the Philippine Commonwealth Army and 3rd Constabulary Regiment of the Philippine Constabulary was liberated in Malolos to helping the local guerrilla resistance fighters of the Bulacan Guerrilla Unit and American troops of the U.S. Army against the Japanese in 1945 at the end of World War II
column6: followed by the appointment of Isberto Crisostomo as civilian town mayor in 1946. The first post-war election was held in 1946 and Carlos Maclang was elected mayor.

column2: Malolos was the site again for another Presidential  inauguration of Joseph Estrada on June 30
column4: in Barasoain Church as the President of the Republic of the Philippines. Estrada
column5: whose real surname is Ejercito
column6: traced his ancestry to the Ejercitos who were prominent in the history of Malolos.

column2: the construction of the Malolos flyover marks a new milestone in their flourishing history being the first in the city. The structure
column3: part of the former Philippine President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo's Bridge Program
column4: the construction was undertaken in a record-breaking 60 days only according to the Department of Public Works and Highways. The structure was built to solve the daily traffic jam at the place
column5: which have become a bane to motorist and also to employees in both private and government offices in this city. This remarkable feat hastened not only the city's development in commerce and trade but its neighboring municipalities as well.

column3: the city was chosen to host the first National Conference for Philippine-Spanish Relations. The conference's theme was "Philippine-Spanish Relations: Sharing Common History and Culture."  This is a project both of the Province of Bulacan's research arm
column4: Center for Bulacan Studies of Bulacan State University and by the Samahang Pangkasaysayan ng Bulacan
column5: Incorporated.

column1: The charter of the City of Malolos was first passed through Republic Act 8754 on November 4
column2: 1999. The bill's author was then Rep. Wilhelmino M. Sy-Alvarado. A plebiscite was conducted on December 18
column4: where the votes "not" in favor of cityhood won. During the plebiscite
column5: the clash between the pro and anti-cityhood groups reached the peak when the allegedly fraud done by the antis to manipulate the results in able to win the "No" votes gathering 11
column6: 535 count against 9
column7: 321 "Yes" votes.

column1: Due to the electoral fraud on Malolos cityhood plebiscite
column2: then Congressman Wilhelmino Alvarado and then Mayor Restituto Roque filed an electoral protest at the Commission on Elections dated December 29
column3: 1999 to recount the results of the plebiscite.The recount reversed the initial decision and the Commission found out that 10
column4: 746 votes approved the cityhood and only 8
column5: 402 against the conversion.

column1: The protest was granted by the Second Division of Commission on Elections
column2: per Resolution No. Election Protest Case 99-2
column3: October 8
column5: the COMELEC affirmed that the "YES" vote won so the Cityhood of Malolos is valid as of December 18

column2: the Malolos City Council passes the City Resolution 24-2010 declaring 18 December of every year to be celebrated as Cityhood Day.

column2: the Philippine Statistics Authority released the official result of 2015 census in which Malolos City has a population of 252
column3: 074 people
column4: with a density of 3
column5: 700 inhabitants per square kilometre or 9
column6: 600 inhabitants per square mile
column7: an increase of 17
column8: 129 people from the 2010 census. There are 47
column9: 362 households in the city. Majority of the Malolos households usually lives along the major roads. It has an average crime rate of 6.28% and has a crime solution efficiency of 97.11%.

column1: The majority of the Maloleños (or Malolenyo in Filipino) traces their roots to Tagalog ethnicity although there are also Kapampangan and other ethnicities who migrated to the city. The vernacular language is Filipino
column2: in the form of Tagalog
column3: while Philippine English is the language most widely used in education and business throughout the city. Although Malolos is the city where the Filipinos established the Spanish as their only official language in the first constitution
column4: the native speakers of Spanish still alive are reduced to the very old members of a handful of families.

column1: Malolos City is subdivided into 51 barangays that are spread over a land area of 7
column2: 725 hectares (19
column3: 090 acres) consisting of agricultural
column4: commercial
column5: industrial
column6: residential
column7: bodies of water
column9: marshes and roads. Many of the name of the barangays were derived from the name of common Philippine trees
column10: because Malolos was once a vast virgin land and forests
column11: before the Spaniards came and Christianized the natives. While others were named in honor of their patron saints.

column1: The Christianization of Malolos was done by the Augustinian Order in May 1572 thru the effort of Fray Diego Vivar-Ordonez (parochial vicar of Calumpit
column2: assistant to Fray Diego Herrera and Martin de Rada) and it became one of the visitas of Parish of Nicolas de Tolentino (became San Juan Bautista in 1576). Since 1572 the apostolic administration in Malolos was under the Convent of Calumpit. On June 11
column3: 1580 the mission chapel was accepted by the Augustinians as House of Order and became Iglesia Convento y Malolos with visitas of Paombong
column4: Matimbo
column5: Mambog and Quingua in 1581. Later due to the frequent high tides that submerged the area
column6: the friars moved the church to its present location in Poblacion in 1590 under the curate Fray Cristobal Tarique
column7: where they started to build a church made of light materials and wood. In 1599 Fray Roque de Barrionuevo started to build a church made of stone and it was finished in 1673. The majority of the residents are Christians. Roman Catholic is the predominant religion in the city.

column2: the Roman Catholic faith in Malolos remained intensive. It is evident through the  existence of the three stone churches. (Malolos Cathedral
column3: Barasoain Church
column4: and the Santa Isabel Church)

column2: Malolos
column3: together with the whole province of Bulacan is constituted as Vicaria dela Immaculada Concepcion in which the (Cura de Malolos is the Vicar Forane). It was part of the Archdiocese of Manila until March 11
column5: when Pope John XXIII created the Diocese of Malolos making the Malolos Church its cathedral. In March 2012 the Diocese of Malolos will celebrate its 50th Anniversary.

column1: It was highlighted by the Canonical Coronation of the patroness and queen of the City and the whole Province
column2: Virgen Inmaculada Concepción de Malolos enshrined at the cathedral's altar.
such as Methodists

Malolos is bounded by municipalities of Calumpit on northwest
column2: Plaridel on north
column3: Guiguinto on east
column4: Paombong on west and Bulacan and Manila Bay on the southeast and south respectively.

column1: Malolos is relatively flat of about 0.81% to a gently sloping of 2.17%. The slope of the land descends towards west
column2: southwest to southern direction. The highest land elevation is at about 6.0 meters above sea level while the lowest is only half a meter below sea level. A network of natural waterways and rivers of various sizes and importance is traversing through the landscape of the town down south to Manila Bay.There are three soil types from the major type of Malolos
column3: the soils of the alluvial landscape and these are the Quingua Series
column4: San Manuel Series and the Tagulod Series. Other soil types comprising the soil map of Malolos are the Matimbo Series and Masantol Series
column5: which belong to the soils of the coastal landscape
column6: Loamy Tidal Swamp and Mucky Tidal Swamp from the miscellaneous soil types.

column1: Malolos belongs to Type 1 category of the Philippine Climate Corona Classification
column2: which has two pronounced seasons
column3: i.e.
column4: wet and dry seasons. Wet during the months of June to November and dry from December to May.The northwest monsoon prevails over the area from October to January bringing in moderate and light rains
column5: the last trade winds predominate from February to April but the high Sierra Madre Mountains interfere with the free circulation of making the area dry with almost no rains during the period
column6: while from May to September the southwest monsoon prevail with strong winds and abundant rainfall
column7: and generally associated with strong typhoon.

column1: The City of Malolos is rapidly becoming commercialized due to its proximity to Metro Manila and for lying between Manila and Clark
column2: Pampanga. Many corporations have put up commercial sites and banking establishments in various places around the city. Many of the businesses and industries in the city include Banking; Business Process Outsourcing; Courier Service; Education; Food Service; Hospitals; Hotels
column3: Resorts & Restaurants; Information and Communications Technology; Insurance; Manpower; ; Realty/Real Property Development; Trade; Transport Services; Travel & Tours; and other services. Robinsons Place Malolos is a major shopping mall owned and operated by Robinsons Malls
column4: the Philippines' second largest mall operator. The mall is located at MacArthur Highway
column5: Barangay Sumapang Matanda. Other shopping malls in Malolos include the Maunlad Malls 1 and 2
column6: both owned and operated by the Union Bank of the Philippines
column7: Graceland Mall
column8: owned and operated by RMR Group of Companies
column10: owned by the Provincial Government of Bulacan.

column1: Chimera Land is an amusement park under construction located in Barangay Sumapang Matanda. Once complete
column2: it will be the first sustainable themed park in the Philippines.Malolos also serves as the Banking Capital of Bulacan
column3: having the highest number of banking institutions in the province (the city hosts around 46)
column4: majority of these are located prominent areas of the city
column5: particularly along Paseo del Congreso Avenue.

column1: Due to its close proximity in Manila and its port
column2: Malolos becomes industrialized. Industrial estates
column3: such as First Bulacan Industrial City
column4: where are more than 20 corporations and companies operating their factories inside the estate are a boom. Mighty Corporation
column5: a major player in the Philippine tobacco industry
column6: operates a tobacco factory in the city.

column2: aquaculture
column3: bag making

column1: Public transportation in Malolos is served by buses
column2: jeepneys
column3: and UV Express AUVs. The city is also served by Tricycles
column4: which offer their services on a for-hire basis.

column1: Malolos is known for its Karatig Jeepneys which serves as an intra-city public transportation. The name itself came from the word karatig
column2: which means nearby places or barangays. The Karatig jeepney is the smaller version of the jeepneys which usually have the size of about 3-meters long and can board 8-10 commuters at the back plus 2 passengers in the front seat. Longer models can accommodate about 10–12. Its capacity varies according to the jeep's length and size. There are two Karatig routes around Malolos.There was a railway service in the city served by the Philippine National Railways. However
column3: in 1988 the North Main Line of the PNR was closed and train services in Malolos ceased immediately. On November 20
column5: in an attempt to revive the railway service
column6: North Luzon Railways Corporation and China National Machinery and Equipment Group (CNMEG) executed a Contract Agreement for the construction of Section I
column7: Phase I of the North Luzon Railway System from Caloocan to Malolos on a turnkey basis. The project was worth $421
column11: 2006 a controversy arose from the project and the project was placed on halt indefinitely. In 2017
column12: the project was revived and was called "North South Commuter Railway" with funds sourced from Japan through a loan. On January 5
column14: the Department of Transportation broke ground for the first phase of the project.

column1: Water services are provided by the City of Malolos Water District (CMWD). The CMWD also provide water services on some barangays in the neighboring towns of Paombong and Hagonoy. Since 2012
column2: the city is suffering from recurring water shortages. Electric services are provided by Meralco
column3: the sole electric power distributor in Malolos.

column1: Malolos is hailed as the Premiere Heritage City of Bulacan. Many ancestral houses from the Spanish and American periods
column2: Spanish colonial churches and chapels
column3: historical sites and landmarks
column4: and even structures such as walls and bridges with heritage and historical value are found around the city. Some of these were already marked by National Historical Institute while others are marked by the City Government. The historic town center of Malolos was declared National Heritage Landmark on August 15
column5: 2001 under the name of Malolos Heritage Town.The Barasoain Church
column6: erected in 1885

column9: and the inauguration of the First Philippine Republic on January 23

column1: Dubbed as the Bulacan's City of Festivals
column2: Malolos boasts with many feasts and festivals every year. Some festivals are civic festivities and most are religious festivals.

column1: Singkaban Festival (Sining at Kalinangan ng Bulacan)
column2: a festival of arts and culture in honor of Capitol's patron saint
column3: "Our Lady of Victory"
column4: showcasing the traditional arts of "Balagtasan"
column5: "Kundiman" and folk dances amidst of the "Singkaban" arches. The festival is celebrated in every second week of September which is in conjunction with the "Linggo ng Bulacan" (Held during September 8–15)
column6: A province-wide
column7: week-long celebration consisting of various colourful cultural presentations
column10: and the prestigious annual Dangal ng Lipi Awards Night and concluding with the anniversary of the opening of the Malolos Congress. Yearly
column11: its activities vary depending upon the chosen theme for the year. This festival is named after the special "BAMBOO ART" abundantly known to the Bulacan province especially in Malolos and Hagonoy where Singkaban Art originated.

column1: Santo Niño de Malolos Festival – This is held during the last Sunday of January
column2: The biggest and largest expression of devotion to the Holy Child Jesus in the Luzon island
column3: celebrated every last Sunday of January. The festivities begin with an exhibit of "Santo Niño" (Holy Child) and culminate in a grand procession of hundreds of folk
column4: antique and new statues of the Holy Child in different depictions. The highlight of this festival is the hundred-year-old antique miraculous image of Senor Sto Nino de Malolos.

column1: Pista ng Santisima Trinidad na Matanda - held annually on Trinity Sunday
column2: it is commonly called Pista ng Santisima Trinidad and other called it "Pista ng Barihan" because Barangays of Barihan
column3: Santisima Trinidad and Pinagbakahan were having one fiesta and one common church in a reason still unknown to the elderly since Spanish period. This fiesta started since the 18th century
column4: where thousands of people from different towns and provinces attending this fiesta and flocks into the Old Chapel to pray for petition and wishes. It is not only at Fiesta but every Fridays and Sundays of the year. It is also dub by the Diocese of Malolos as "Quiapo ng Bulacan". The Fiesta highlights is the public exposition of the miraculous and highly venerated antique icons of the Holy Trinity
column5: during procession attended by other holy images from all parts of the province.The four holy processional icons are:

column1: Santisima Trinidad de Mayor - oil on canvas
column2: the back of the canvass exposed a date of January 10
column4: and is thus the oldest Catholic icon in the Philippines. It is considered very miraculous by majority faithful.

column1: Santisima Trinidad na Bata - oil on rosewood
column2: a 1762 icon is the second-oldest among the processional icons.

column1: Santisima Trinidad de Trisagio - the last and youngest of the three holy icons depicting the "biblical trinity"

column2: the Santisima Trinidad de Original
column3: it was the nucleus of the chapel
column4: the site was farmland. This icon was enshrined in the Santisima Trinidad Chapel's main retablo. Sadly it was stolen on October 27
column6: after Pistang Maliit and remains lost.All of these antique and miraculous images are in the custody of the Bisitang Matanda ng Santisima Trinidad and can be visited and seen at the houses of the designated annual Hermano.

column1: Pabukang Puso — held every March 19 in Panasahan
column2: commemorates the death of St. Joseph the Worker
column3: Foster-father of Jesus. It is annually held at the front house of Roxas clan in Panasahan
column4: whose patriarch
column5: Valentin Roxas
column6: started it in 1975. This tradition still continues until present day where the younger generations of the clan organising it.

column1: Malolos is hailed as one of the centers of education in Central Luzon region. It has several universities such as the government-funded Bulacan State University
column2: and privately owned Centro Escolar University at Malolos and La Consolacion University Philippines. There are private tertiary schools. It also houses the most populous high school in Central Luzon
column3: Marcelo H. del Pilar National High School
column4: founded in 1905.

column1: The city has 9 public high schools and 45 public elementary schools under the authority of Department of Education Division of City Schools of Malolos. The city schools are divided into two educational districts for representational purposes. There are also privately owned and church-operated schools established in the city. These private schools are members of Malolos City Private schools Association (MACIPRISA). Technical schools and computer colleges can also be found in the city.
The Malolos City hosts more than 51 residential subdivisions and the Northville 8 Resettlement Project of the Philippine government.

The City Health Office of Malolos is responsible for the planning and implementation of the health care programs provided by the city government. It currently operates seven health centers. The Bulacan Medical Center (formerly Bulacan Provincial Hospital)
column2: operated by the provincial government of Bulacan
column3: is also located in the city.

column1: Private hospitals can also be found in the city. Some of the private hospitals that operate in the city are Sacred Heart Hospital
column2: Santos General Hospital
column3: Malolos Maternity Hospital
column4: Malolos San Ildefonso County Hospital
column5: Ofelia Mendoza Maternity and General Hospital
column6: and the Graman Medical and Maternity Hospital.
